title: What is a good thesis statement for teenage pregnancy? - Quora

response.answer_text: Globally, teenage pregnancy is a significant challenge adversely affecting the physical and psychological health of the teen – this is one example of a strong and good thesis statement. A three-pronged thesis statement includes three reasons in the statement to support the thesis. Using the same example given above, a three-part thesis statement would be - Globally, teenage pregnancy is a significant challenge adversely affecting the physical and psychological health of the teen, the socio-economic status of her family, and the consequences to society as a whole. A good thesis statement ties together the main idea of your topic and research paper. It should be informative, persuasive, and a declaration of your intentions concerning the subject. Format of a Good Thesis Statement Teenage pregnancy is a vast topic. Narrow down available data and decide the area to wish to focus on. 1. Express the Main Idea: Form a thesis statement to express the main idea of your essay or research paper. It should be a summary of the points you are going to make in your paper. It should showcase the highlights of your essay. It is called a statement with reason! In the case of teenage pregnancy, you can decide if you want to talk about the reasons, mitigation, prevention, health impact, challenges faced, personal awareness, etc. 2. Be Focused: Your thesis statement should be specific. The thesis statement is only one single sentence. Therefore, you have to make it on target. It has to reflect the very soul of the topic. Moreover, it is easier to research well-specified objectives. It also prevents you from losing direction and rambling on unrelated facts. Do not generalize. Make targeted claims, with relevant points. In the example given, it clearly states that we are going to discuss the impact of teenage pregnancy on the teen, family, and society. 3. Summarize Points: Make and list out all valid points which you can support later, with authentic evidence from credible sources. When using the word "globally" substantiate with a broad list of statistics from various countries. Specify and list out differences in the pattern that you can see in developed and developing countries, etc. In some countries with early marriage, it could be a planned pregnancy. Hence the impact of a planned teenage pregnancy against unplanned teen pregnancy. 4. Defend your Points: When you compose a thesis statement, be prepared to defend it with valid evidence. Back your points with research and supporting claims. Present your views in a way that the reader cares to read it through. In the example given, when you say pregnancy affects the physical and psychological health of the teenager, specify the why and how. Immature bodies, unplanned pregnancy cause mental trauma, fear, malnutrition, etc. 5. Take into Account the Reader Viewpoint: Develop your thesis statement from reader viewpoint, and not just your personal opinion. Consider all input and respect reader outlook and perspective. The thesis statement should grab and hold the attention of the reader. It is the window to your paper. Therefore, dress this window with a reader-friendly, appropriate, and exciting statement. The first paragraph in the introduction part of your research paper or essay should carry the thesis statement. Research your topic well. Present your insights in a logical manner. The main points of your thesis statement will form the foundation on which your paper will rest. It will ensure the smooth flow of each argument into the next. Compose it in a way which paves a smooth path for the main body of your thesis. Remember, a good thesis statement expresses the main idea and takes a stand.

Depends on what you are arguing. I wouldn' say something simple like “teen pregnancy is bad.” Say it is bad in regards to… decide what about teen pregnancy you want to argue. effects on psychological health? effects on socioeconomic status? effects on the body? effect on family? and then list a few supporting details. An example might be: “pregnancy is detrimental to the psychological health of teenagers; Resulting effects can include increased rates of depression, emotional and hormonal imbalances, and ultimately result in a lower socioeconomic status of the mother and child.” thats completely made up off the top of my head. You would want to include information from your research. The main point of your paper should be in the thesis. Then the supporting details of the thesis become the main topics of the body paragraphs. The thesis is basically a roadmap of your paper. When you read it you should know what the paper is going to be about and where the paper is going to go with its explanation. In each of the body paragraphs, you will explain and prove those supporting details from your thesis.
